Peace over Laos?
The dubious assumptions of Vietnamization have
been shattered by the invasion of Laos and the vast
increase in United States' bombing in the Indochina
War. Nixon's non-plan of gradual withdrawal seems
to have lulled the anti-war movement to sleep. Nixon
and his Administration believe that because it's cold
outside, and because he didn't make a dramatic plea
for patriotism, thereby opening the floodgates to
rebuff, Laos will not be another Cambodia--at least.
not on the domestic scene. He hopes that come
,spring --speculation is April--the big Laos thrust will
the North Vietnamese supply schedule will have been
set back dramatically, and he will be able to
announce a "significant withdrawal" of u.U.S.
combat troops--a tried and true domestic pacifier.
Hopefully, the peace forces in this country will
brave the cold and make it a little more difficult for
Mr. Nixon to bide his time and further expand the
war. Hopefully, they will try to persuade those as yet
unconverted that what the President is doing may
eventually lead to an American pullout, but it will be
a pullout tainted with the dishonor--the blood of an
even wider war and one that, because of our
presence, will surely go on for many years after we
have gone.
The fact is that if there had been no protests, no
marches on Washington, no peace candidates, we
would likely be in a far more serious confrontation
than we are now.
The peace movement has taught a whole
generation to oppose the imperialist basis of United
States foreign policy. Still, we are not out of
Indochina. That should be our main goal, and we are
far from achieving it. With the invasion of Laos, the
anti-war movement has rolled over and played dead.
Wednesday's demonstrations could barely draw a
crowd, and the leadership of the anti-war movement
has simply not stepped forward. From Fulbright to
Tom Hayden to the Weathermen, there has been, at
least in public, a passive acceptance of the Nixon
escalation.
So, it is up to us. Starting from the bottom, like the
original opponents in the early sixties, we have to
build outward from the campuses once again. The
pressure has to come from somewhere and we had
better provide it or be prepared to watch the
Indochina War become a permanent fixture of
national life.

Gilman Clock
For scores of years, as generations of Hopkins
students stirred restlessly in their classroom seats,
the Gilman clock would play its little tune to their
straining ears. Pencils would stop scratching against
notebooks as the students would count the number of
measures that the clock rang out. One measure, and
even though they thought the class must surely be
just about over, only fifteen minutes had elapsed.
Two measures, and the suffering was half gone.
Three measures, and productive activity nearly
ceased as the class would start packing up.
But now,a misdirected austerity move has silenced
this Homewood mainstay. Professors have no idea of
the time and continue their monologue until the
monotonous bong stops them and then it is too late to
make the next class. It couldn't cost that much to fix
this precious tradition, which now stands idle in
disrepair, and so we urge that the administration
move quickly to get the bells ringing across the
Keyser guadrangle once again.
